question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the questions regarding Elon Musk's attendance at Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and the recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module, I considered various factors that could influence each event's likelihood. 

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: Given Musk's prominence in the cryptocurrency space and his past involvement in similar events, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend the conference. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P and thus directly related. If P is high, not_P will be low. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This is closely related to P, as it essentially asks the same question in a different way. The probability should be aligned with P, hence I expect it to be similar. 

4. **Q (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module)**: This event is much more uncertain due to the unknown location of the module and the challenges involved in space recovery. I estimate a lower probability here compared to P. 

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The probability of both P and Q happening is expected to be lower than either P or Q alone, as they are independent events. However, if either event is highly unlikely, this probability will reflect that. 

6. **P_or_Q (At least one event occurring)**: This probability should be higher than both individual probabilities, as it accounts for the occurrence of either event. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Apollo 10 recovery and Musk not showing up)**: This asks for the conjunction of two independent events, and its probability should reflect the likelihood of both occurring simultaneously. 

8. **Q_given_P (Recovery given Musk's attendance)**: This conditional probability might suggest that if Musk attends, it may increase the interest or resources available for the recovery of the module, potentially raising this probability compared to Q alone. 

Overall, I will ensure that the probabilities respect the consistency rules provided, such as the relationships between P and not_P, and the conjunctions and disjunctions of the events.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates or combinations will resolve as **No**. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

In this forecasting scenario, we have two main events: whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P) and whether the Apollo 10 Lunar Module will be recovered by 2050 (Q). These events are somewhat independent but can also be related through their joint probabilities in the context of the questions posed.

### Predictions:
1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: Given Musk's prominence in the cryptocurrency space and his previous involvement in Bitcoin-related events, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending the conference. This is influenced by the timing and significance of the event.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P, reflecting the uncertainty regarding his attendance.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This is expected to be high, similar to P, as it reflects the same event from a different angle, indicating the likelihood of him being present.

4. **Q (Apollo 10 Lunar Module recovery)**: This event is more uncertain due to the unknowns surrounding the location of the module and the challenges of recovering it. Therefore, I estimate a lower probability for this event compared to P.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The joint probability of both events occurring is expected to be lower than either event occurring independently, as there is no direct causal relationship between Musk's attendance and the recovery of the Lunar Module.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This probability will be higher than the individual probabilities of P and Q but less than 1, as it accounts for the possibility of either event occurring.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Recovery of Lunar Module while Musk does not show up)**: This probability is expected to be low, as it combines the uncertainty of Q with the certainty that Musk is not attending.

8. **Q_given_P (Recovery of Lunar Module given Musk's attendance)**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of the Lunar Module's recovery if Musk is at the conference. While P does not directly affect Q, it may influence perceptions or media coverage, potentially increasing interest in the recovery efforts.

### Independence and Relationships:
- P and Q are generally independent events; however, their joint probabilities and conditional probabilities may reflect indirect relationships based on shared context (e.g., media attention).

### Consistency Rules:
- The probabilities must adhere to the consistency rules outlined, such as the complementarity of P and not_P, the relationships between joint and individual probabilities, and the bounds established by the maximum and minimum values for combinations of probabilities. I will ensure that my estimates respect these rules in the final output.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and (2) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(1) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

This resolves Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(2) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?

This resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

The Lunar Module flown on Apollo 10 is the only flown lunar module which didn't end up crashing into the Moon or burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
After 'dress rehearsal' testing in lunar orbit, during which the Lunar Module came within 8.4 nautical miles of the lunar surface, the ascent engine performed a burn to depletion which sent the craft into interplanetary space and the vehicle is currently in a heliocentric orbit. The location of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is unknown as of May 2019, but efforts are underway to find it.
As a unique historical artefact from the original golden age of human spaceflight, this Lunar Module would certainly make for an interesting museum exhibit.
This question asks: by 1 January 2050, will the lost ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be recovered (i.e. located, captured, and physically transported to some location where humans have a presence at that time, such as Earth, the Moon, Mars or elsewhere) successfully?

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: The probability of this event is influenced by Elon Musk's past behaviors and involvement in cryptocurrency events. Given his prominence in the Bitcoin community, I would estimate a moderate to high probability of attendance, perhaps around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is estimated at 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a possibility that Elon Musk will attend Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: Since this question is effectively asking the same thing as P, I would assign a similar probability of around 0.65.

4. **Q (Apollo 10's Lunar Module recovery by 2050)**: The recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module is uncertain due to its current location being unknown. Given the historical significance and ongoing efforts to locate it, I would estimate a lower probability, perhaps around 0.25.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability would be the product of the individual probabilities if we assume independence. Thus, P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.65 * 0.25 = 0.1625.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This would be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Therefore, P_or_Q = 0.65 + 0.25 - 0.1625 = 0.7375.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and P does not)**: This would be calculated as Q * not_P, which gives us Q_and_not_P = 0.25 * 0.35 = 0.0875.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur)**: This is a conditional probability and would likely be higher than the unconditional Q due to the context of Musk's involvement potentially increasing interest and funding for space recovery efforts. I would estimate this around 0.35.

Overall, I expect that P and Q are somewhat independent events but may have slight correlations due to the nature of public interest in both cryptocurrency and space exploration.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (b) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, this part resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This part may consider new candidates added in the future.

The question will resolve as "No" if either of these conditions is not met.

In this scenario, we have two main events: (1) Elon Musk showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P) and (2) the recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module by 2050 (Q). These events are largely independent but can influence each other in the context of the combined questions.

### Predictions:
1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: Given his history with Bitcoin and cryptocurrency events, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend, say around 0.60. This reflects his past engagements and the significance of the event.
2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This would simply be 1 - P, which would be 0.40.
3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: Since this is essentially the same as P, I will set this at 0.60 as well.
4. **Q (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module)**: This is a more uncertain event given the unknowns about the module's location and the efforts required to recover it. I estimate this at a lower probability, perhaps 0.25.
5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The probability of both events happening can be calculated using the independence assumption: P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.60 * 0.25 = 0.15.
6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This is calculated as P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q = 0.60 + 0.25 - 0.15 = 0.70.
7. **Q_and_not_P (Q happening while P does not)**: This is calculated as Q_and_not_P = Q * not_P = 0.25 * 0.40 = 0.10.
8. **Q_given_P (Q occurring given P happens)**: This is essentially asking for the conditional probability. Given that P occurs, the likelihood of Q might increase slightly due to potential collaborative efforts or media attention, so I would estimate this at around 0.30.

### Relationship and Independence:
The events P and Q are independent in the sense that the occurrence of one does not directly affect the other. However, they are related in the context of the combined questions (P_and_Q and Q_and_not_P). The calculations must respect the consistency rules outlined, ensuring that the probabilities align correctly across the various combinations. 

Overall, the estimates should be carefully calibrated to ensure adherence to the consistency rules, particularly those involving conjunctions and disjunctions of events.

Otherwise, resolves NO.

In this scenario, we are evaluating a series of binary forecasting questions related to two main events: Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and the potential recovery of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module by 2050. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This prediction is influenced by Musk's past engagements and his general interest in Bitcoin and cryptocurrency. Given the popularity of the event, I estimate a moderate probability of 0.60 that he will attend.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P, so it should be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This is closely related to P, and since it essentially asks the same question in a different phrasing, I can assign it the same probability of 0.60.

4. **Q (Apollo 10 Lunar Module recovery by 2050)**: The recovery of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is uncertain due to its location being unknown. Historical context suggests a lower probability, so I estimate this at 0.25.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occur)**: The likelihood of both events happening is lower than either happening independently. I estimate this at 0.15.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurs)**: This probability should encompass scenarios where at least one of the events occurs. Given the individual probabilities, I estimate this at 0.65.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Recovery of the Lunar Module and Musk not attending)**: This is a more specific scenario, and I estimate this at 0.10, given the independence of the two events.

8. **Q_given_P (Recovery of the Lunar Module given Musk's attendance)**: This is a conditional probability. If Musk attends, it doesn't necessarily affect the likelihood of the Lunar Module being recovered, so I estimate this at 0.25.

Overall, the predictions are interrelated, particularly P and not_P, which are complements, while P_and_Q and Q_and_not_P are more dependent on their respective events happening or not. I will ensure that the probability estimates respect the consistency rules outlined.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). Resolves NO otherwise. Note: Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not impact the resolution as long as he remains President.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: The probability of this event will depend on various factors such as Musk's schedule, interest in Bitcoin, and the significance of the event. Given Musk's previous engagement with cryptocurrency, I would estimate a moderate probability for this event.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P as moderately likely, not_P will be correspondingly less likely. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of Elon Musk attending)**: This is closely related to P and should have a similar probability estimate since it asks about the potential of his attendance.

4. **Q (Apollo 10 Lunar Module recovery by 2050)**: This question is quite speculative, as it involves a historical artifact and the efforts to locate it. Depending on the advancements in technology and interest in space exploration, I would estimate a lower probability for this event due to the uncertainty surrounding the recovery.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The probability of both events happening is likely to be lower than either event happening independently, as they are not directly related but are contingent on two different factors. 

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: The probability of either event occurring should be higher than the individual probabilities of P and Q, as it encompasses both possibilities. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Apollo 10 recovery and Musk not showing up)**: This scenario combines the probability of Q with the negation of P, which again should yield a lower probability than either event happening alone.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will Apollo 10 be recovered?)**: This conditional probability might be higher than Q alone, as it assumes that Musk's presence could potentially have a positive impact on the recovery efforts of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module.

Overall, I will ensure that all the probability estimates respect the consistency rules provided, especially focusing on the relationships between P, not_P, Q, and their combinations. question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating the likelihood of two main events: (1) Elon Musk showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and (2) the recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module by 2050. 

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: The probability of Elon Musk attending a significant Bitcoin conference is influenced by his past engagement with the cryptocurrency community and his public persona. Given his history of participating in such events, I estimate a moderate to high probability for him to show up, let's say around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is the complementary event to P. If I estimate P at 0.60, then not_P would be 1 - 0.60 = 0.40.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This question is closely related to P and would likely have a similar probability estimate, as it essentially asks the same thing but in a different phrasing. I would set this at 0.60 as well.

4. **Q (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module)**: The recovery of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is a complex task that depends on various factors including technological advancements and funding. Given the uncertainty surrounding this event, I estimate a lower probability, perhaps around 0.25.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The occurrence of both events is dependent on both P and Q happening simultaneously. To estimate this, I would use the product of their probabilities, assuming some level of independence: P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.60 * 0.25 = 0.15.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This is calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Substituting the values gives us: P_or_Q = 0.60 + 0.25 - 0.15 = 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module while Musk does not show up)**: This is a more complex relationship, but assuming some level of independence, I would estimate this at Q * not_P = 0.25 * 0.40 = 0.10.

8. **Q_given_P (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module given Musk shows up)**: This conditional probability could be higher than Q alone if Musk's presence somehow influences the recovery efforts. I might estimate this at around 0.30.

Overall, these events are interrelated, with the attendance of Musk being a more social and public event while the recovery of the Lunar Module is a technical and historical endeavor. The estimates reflect a balance between optimism about Musk's engagement with Bitcoin and skepticism about the feasibility of recovering a lost spacecraft. The probabilities must respect the consistency rules laid out, meaning that the relationships between these events must be mathematically sound.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from any U.S. state's primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

2. Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. 

The question will resolve as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.
